docs.lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration has announced an initiative to cut salt in packaged and restaurant foods by 25 percent over the next five years. Public health experts say these changes would reduce the incidence of high blood pressure and help prevent some strokes and heart attacks.

headline.main: Big Brother and the Salt Shaker

docs.abstract: Should government try to monitor and modify how we eat?
docs.snippet: Should government try to monitor and modify how we eat?

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, Jan. 15, 9:20 a.m. | With traffic jammed at Port-au-Prince airport, relief groups are considering moving emergency supplies through the neighboring Dominican Republic and the use of land-sea vessels to unload supplies at the badly damaged port in the Haitian capital.
docs.abstract: Given Haiti's political instability and crumbling infrastructure, what kind of aid should be sent and how?
docs.snippet: Given Haiti's political instability and crumbling infrastructure, what kind of aid should be sent and how?

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In previous posts, Dr. Crowe exploredthe varied symptoms of celiac disease and confirming a diagnosis of celiac disease. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers asking about the disease running in families, genetic tests that may help confirm a diagnosis, food allergies and thins that set off the ailment.
docs.abstract: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on genes and celiac disease.
docs.snippet: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on genes and celiac disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: The legalization of medical marijuana in New Jersey is a welcome show of compassion for the chronically ill and should become a model for other states.
docs.snippet: The legalization of medical marijuana in New Jersey is a welcome show of compassion for the chronically ill and should become a model for other states.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In a previous post, Dr. Crowe explained how celiac disease can present not just with digestive complaints, but also anemia and other conditions. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers wondering what tests should be requested to confirm a diagnosis of celiac disease.

headline.main: Confirming a Diagnosis of Celiac Disease

docs.abstract: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on the diagnosis of celiac disease.
docs.snippet: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on the diagnosis of celiac disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, American ideas about psychiatric disorders have spread around the globe. Is that really good for the world’s mental health?
docs.snippet: In recent years, American ideas about psychiatric disorders have spread around the globe. Is that really good for the world’s mental health?

docs.lead_paragraph: Donating life-saving bone marrow cells is safe. The law should allow it.
docs.snippet: Donating life-saving bone marrow cells is safe. The law should allow it.

byline.original: By JOHN WAGNER and JEFF ROWES

docs.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday proposed a stricter standard for smog-causing pollutants that would bring substantial health benefits to millions of Americans while imposing large costs on industry and local governments. The standard would replace one set by the Bush administration in March 2008, which has been challenged in court by state officials and environmental advocates as too weak to adequately protect human health and the environment.

headline.main: E.P.A. Seeks Tighter Rules To Cut Down Air Pollution

docs.abstract: Environmental Protection Agency proposes stricter standard for smog-causing pollutants that will bring substantial health benefits to millions of Americans while imposing large costs on industry and local governments; rules will replace standard set by Bush administration in March 2008, challenged as too weak to adequately protect human health and environment; Obama administration proposal sets primary standards for ground-level ozone to be phased in over two decades; regions with worst smog pollution, including much of Northeast, Southern and Central California and other areas, will have more time to come into compliance; proposal includes secondary smog standard that will vary with seasons; EPA estimates that complying with new standards will cost $19 billion-$90 billion per year by 2020 but emphasizes that costs will be offset by benefits to human health, valued at $13 billion-$100 billion per year in same period; state and local governments will have to impose regulations to reduce smog-causing pollutants in areas that do not meet new standards, thought to be some 515 counties; photo; map; chart (L)
docs.snippet: If adopted, the standard will impose large costs on local governments and industry but will also bring substantial health benefits.

multimedia.credit: If adopted, the proposal will impose large costs on industry and local governments, but will also bring substantial health benefits to millions of Americans.
multimedia.caption: New Rules Proposed for Smog Pollutants
